[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The variance value

Mean Square Error (MSE) Functions

These functions compute the MSE value between two vectors.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ MSE = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=0}^{N} \left(src1[i] - src2[i]\right)^{\scriptscriptstyle{2}} } \]

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: F32, F16, F64, Q15, Q31, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_mse_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_mse_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size, float32_t * result)
Description

Function that computes the Mean Square Error (MSE) value between two F32 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

riscv_vec_mse_f16

Declaration
void riscv_vec_mse_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size, float16_t * result)
Description

Function that computes the Mean Square Error (MSE) between two F16 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_vec_mse_f64

Declaration
void riscv_vec_mse_f64 (const float64_t * src1, const float64_t * src2, uint32_t size, float64_t * result)
Description

Function that computes the Mean Square Error (MSE) between two F64 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

riscv_vec_mse_q31

Declaration
void riscv_vec_mse_q31 (const q31_t * src1, const q31_t * src2, uint32_t size, q31_t * result)
Description

Function that computes the Mean Square Error (MSE) between two Q31 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

riscv_vec_mse_q15

Declaration
void riscv_vec_mse_q15 (const q15_t * src1, const q15_t * src2, uint32_t size, q15_t * result)
Description

Function that computes the Mean Square Error (MSE) between two Q15 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

riscv_vec_mse_q7

Declaration
void riscv_vec_mse_q7 (const q7_t * src1, const q7_t * src2, uint32_t size, q7_t * result)
Description

Function that computes the Mean Square Error (MSE) between two Q7 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

[out] result

Pointer to the MSE value
Returns

None

Entropy Functions

These functions compute the entropy of a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ Entropy = - \left(\sum_{i=0}^{\mathtt{size-1}} src[i] * \mathtt{{ln}(src[i])} \right) } \]

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_entropy_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_vec_entropy_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Description

Entropy function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The entropy value

riscv_vec_entropy_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_vec_entropy_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Description

Entropy function for F16.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The entropy value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_vec_entropy_f64

Declaration
float64_t riscv_vec_entropy_f64 (const float64_t * src, uint32_t size)
Description

Entropy function for F64.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The entropy value

Relative Entropy Functions

These functions compute the entropy of two vectors, commonly referred to as the Kullback-Leibler divergence (DKL).

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ D_{\scriptscriptstyle{KL}}(src1 \, \| \, src2) = - \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} src1[i] * \mathtt{ln}\left(\frac{src2[i]}{src1[i]}\right) \right) } \]

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_relative_entropy_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_vec_relative_entropy_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Description

Relative entropy function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The relative entropy value

riscv_vec_relative_entropy_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_vec_relative_entropy_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Description

Relative entropy function for F16.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The relative entropy value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_vec_relative_entropy_f64

Declaration
float64_t riscv_vec_relative_entropy_f64 (const float64_t * src1, const float64_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Description

Relative entropy function for F64.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The relative entropy value

Log-Sum-Exp (LSE) Functions

These functions compute the logarithm of the sum of exponentials applied to a vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[$$ \mathtt{ LSE(src_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \, \dots, \, src_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}) = src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} + \mathtt{log\left(\mathtt{exp\left(src_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}} - src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)} + \dots + \mathtt{exp\left(src_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}} - src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)}\right)} } $$\]

where \(\mathtt{src^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} = \mathtt{max\{src_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \, \dots, \, src_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}\}}}\).

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_lse_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_vec_lse_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Description

LSE function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The LSE value

riscv_vec_lse_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_vec_lse_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Description

LSE function for F16.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The LSE value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Log-Sum-Exp (LSE) Dot Product Functions

These functions compute the logarithm of the sum of exponentials applied to the dot product of two vectors.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[$$ \mathtt{ LSE(X_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \, \dots, \, X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}) = X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} + \mathtt{log\left(\mathtt{\exp\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}} - X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)} + \dots + \mathtt{exp\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}} - X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}}\right)}\right)} } $$\]

where \(\mathtt{X^{\scriptscriptstyle{*}} = \mathtt{max\{X_{\scriptscriptstyle{1}}, \dots, X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}}\}, \, X_{\scriptscriptstyle{n}} = src1[n] + src2[n]}}\).

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_lse_dprod_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_vec_lse_dprod_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Description

LSE dot product function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The LSE dot product value

riscv_vec_lse_dprod_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_vec_lse_dprod_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Description

LSE dot product function for F16.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Returns

The LSE dot product value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Naive Gaussian Bayesian Estimation Functions

These functions implement the naive Gaussian Bayes estimator.

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f32

Declaration
uint32_t riscv_vec_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f32 (const riscv_vec_gaussian_naivebayes_f32_t * instance, const float32_t * src, float32_t * buf)
Description

Naive Gaussian Bayesian estimation function for F32.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_gaussian_naivebayes_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 naive Gaussian Bayesian estimation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t dimofvec;
    uint32_t numofclass;
    const float32_t * mean;
    const float32_t * var;
    const float32_t * classprior;
    float32_t additiveofvar;
} riscv_vec_gaussian_naivebayes_f32_t;

where:

dimofvec

Dimension of vector space

numofclass

Number of classes

mean

Mean value for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

var

Variance for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

classprior

Class prior probabilities whose size is numofclass

additiveofvar

Additive value of variance

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] buf

Pointer to the buffer vector
Returns

The estimated class

riscv_vec_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f16

Declaration
uint32_t riscv_vec_gaussian_naive_bayes_est_f16 (const riscv_vec_gaussian_naivebayes_f16_t * instance, const float16_t * src, float16_t * buf)
Description

Naive Gaussian Bayesian estimation function for F32.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_gaussian_naivebayes_f16_t

Instance structure of the F16 naive Gaussian Bayesian estimation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t dimofvec;
    uint32_t numofclass;
    const float16_t * mean;
    const float16_t * var;
    const float16_t * classprior;
    float16_t additiveofvar;
} riscv_vec_gaussian_naivebayes_f16_t;

where:

dimofvec

Dimension of vector space

numofclass

Number of classes

mean

Mean value for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

var

Variance for the Gaussian whose size is dimofvec * numofclass

classprior

Class prior probabilities whose size is numofclass

additiveofvar

Additive value of variance

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] buf

Pointer to the buffer vector
Returns

The estimated class

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Accumulation Functions

These functions compute the accumulation of the input vector.

The behavior can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ accum\_sum = \sum_{i=0}^{N-1} \left(src[i]\right) } \]

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single-, half-, and double-precision floating-point, Q31, Q15, Q7, and U8. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_accum_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_vec_accum_f32 (const float32_t * src, uint32_t size)
Description

Accumulation function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed
Returns

The accumulation result

riscv_vec_accum_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_vec_accum_f16 (const float16_t * src, uint32_t size)
Description

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed
Returns

The accumulation result

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) Function

This function implements the SNR function which can be defined as follows:

\[ \mathtt{ SNR = 10 * log_{\scriptscriptstyle{10}}\left(\frac{P_{\scriptscriptstyle{signal}}}{P_{\scriptscriptstyle{noise}}}\right) } \]

VEC Library only supports the function for the F32 data type. The function is described in the subsection below.

riscv_vec_snr_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_vec_snr_f32 (float32_t * signal, loat32_t * noise, uint32_t size)
Description

SNR function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] signal

Pointer to the input signal vector

[in] noise

Pointer to the input noise vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed
Returns

The SNR result

Support Vector Machine (SVM) Estimation Functions

These functions implement two-class SVM classification based on the provided instance structure.

SVM Linear Estimation Functions

This section describes the SVM linear estimation functions.

riscv_vec_svm_linear_est_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_svm_linear_est_f32 (const riscv_vec_svm_linear_f32_t * instance, const float32_t * src, int32_t * result)
Description

SVM linear estimation function for F32.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_svm_linear_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 SVM linear estimator, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t numofvec;
    uint32_t dimofvec;
    float32_t intercept;
    const float32_t * dualcoe;
    const float32_t * vec;
    const int32_t * classes;
} riscv_vec_svm_linear_f32_t;

where:

numofvec

Number of support vectors

dimofvec

Dimension of vector space

intercept

Intercept

dualcoe

Pointer to the dual coefficients

vec

Pointer to the support vectors

classes

Pointer to the 2 classes ID

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] result

Pointer to the output decision class

riscv_vec_svm_linear_est_f16

Declaration
void riscv_vec_svm_linear_est_f16 (const riscv_vec_svm_linear_f16_t * instance, const float16_t * src, int32_t * result)
Description

SVM linear estimation function for F16.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_svm_linear_f16_t

Instance structure of the F16 SVM linear estimator, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t numofvec;
    uint32_t dimofvec;
    float16_t intercept;
    const float16_t * dualcoe;
    const float16_t * vec;
    const int32_t * classes;
} riscv_vec_svm_linear_f16_t;

where:

numofvec

Number of support vectors

dimofvec

Dimension of vector space

intercept

Intercept

dualcoe

Pointer to the dual coefficients

vec

Pointer to the support vectors

classes

Pointer to the 2 classes ID

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] result

Pointer to the output decision class
Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

intercept

dualcoe

riscv_vec_svm_poly_est_f32

SVM polynomial estimation function for F32.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_svm_poly_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 SVM polynomial estimator, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t numofvec;
    uint32_t dimofvec;
    float32_t intercept;
    const float32_t * dualcoe;
    const float32_t * vec;
    const int32_t * classes;
    int32_t exponent;
    float32_t coef0;
    float32_t gamma;
} riscv_vec_svm_poly_f32_t;

where:

numofvec

Number of support vectors

dimofvec

Dimension of vector space

intercept

Intercept

dualcoe

Pointer to the dual coefficients

vec

Pointer to the support vectors

classes

Pointer to the 2 classes ID

exponent

Polynomial exponent

coef0

Independent constant

gamma

Gamma factor

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] result

Pointer to the output decision class

classes

Pointer to the 2 classes ID

coef0

Independent constant

gamma

Gamma factor

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] result

Pointer to the output decision class
Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Distance Functions

These functions compute the distance between two vectors.

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: single- and half-precision floating-point. These functions are described in the subsections below.

Float Distance Functions

These functions compute the distance between two vectors of float values: F32 and F16.

VEC Library supports algorithms for calculating the following distances:

  • Bray-Curtis distance

  • Canberra distance

  • Chebyshev distance

  • Cityblock (Manhattan) distance

  • Correlation distance

  • Cosine distance

  • Euclidean distance

  • Jensen-Shannon distance

  • Minkowski distance

riscv_vec_dist_bray_curtis_f32

Declaration
float32_t riscv_vec_dist_bray_curtis_f32 (const float32_t * src1, const float32_t * src2, uint32_t size)
Description

Bray-Curtis distance between two F32 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src1

Pointer to the first input vector

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed
Returns

The distance value

riscv_vec_dist_bray_curtis_f16

Declaration
float16_t riscv_vec_dist_bray_curtis_f16 (const float16_t * src1, const float16_t * src2, uint32_t size)

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src2

Pointer to the second input vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed
Returns

The distance value

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) Distance Functions

These functions compute the DTW distance between the input F32 distance matrix and input Q7 window matrix, which can be NULL (representing a full-range computation) or a result computed from riscv_vec_dtw_init_window_q7. Additionally, it can compute the DTW path using riscv_vec_dtw_path_f32.

riscv_vec_dtw_distance_f32

Declaration
int riscv_vec_dtw_distance_f32 (const float32_t * dtw_src, const q7_t * dtw_window, float32_t * dtw_out, float32_t * dtw_distance, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Description

DTW distance function.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] dtw_src

Pointer to the input distance matrix

[in] dtw_window

Pointer to the input window matrix

[out] dtw_out

Pointer to the output DTW cost matrix

[out] dtw_distance

Pointer to the output DTW distance

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if no path can be found due to window constraints

riscv_vec_dtw_path_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_dtw_path_f32 (const float32_t *dtw, int16_t *dtw_path, uint32_t *dtw_path_length, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Description

DTW path compute function.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] dtw

Pointer to the input DTW cost matrix

[out] dtw_path

Pointer to the output DTW path vector

[out] dtw_path_length

Pointer to the output Number of path length

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix

riscv_vec_dtw_init_window_q7

Declaration
int riscv_vec_dtw_init_window_q7 (const riscv_vec_dtw_window_type window_type, const int32_t window_size, q7_t * dtw_window, uint32_t row, uint32_t col)
Description

DTW window compute function.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] window_type

Type of window

[in] window_size

Size of window

[out] dtw_window

Pointer to the output window matrix

[in] row

Number of rows in a matrix

[in] col

Number of columns in a matrix
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if window_type is not supported

Note

Supported window types for riscv_vec_dtw_window_type include:

RISCV_VEC_DTW_SAKOE_CHIBA_WINDOW

SAKOE_CHIBA window type

RISCV_VEC_DTW_SLANTED_BAND_WINDOW

SLANTED_BAND window type

Sorting Functions

This section describes the sorting functions.

Generic Sorting Functions

These functions sort elements of a vector by the sorting order specified in the input parameter.

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: F32, Q31, q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_sort_f32

Declaration
int riscv_vec_sort_f32 (float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size, riscv_vec_sort_order order)
Description

Sorting function for F32 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed

[in] order

Sorting order
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if order is not supported

Note

The available sorting orders for generic sorting (i.e., options for order) are:

RISCV_VEC_SORT_DESCENDING

Descending order

RISCV_VEC_SORT_ASCENDING

Ascending order

riscv_vec_sort_q31

Declaration
int riscv_vec_sort_q31 (q31_t * src, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size, riscv_vec_sort_order order)
Description

Sorting function for Q31 vectors.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed

[in] order

Sorting order
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if order is not supported

Note

  • Supported sorting orders for generic sorting (i.e., options for order) include:

    RISCV_VEC_SORT_DESCENDING

    Descending order

    RISCV_VEC_SORT_ASCENDING

    Ascending order

riscv_vec_sort_q15

int riscv_vec_sort_q15 (q15_t * src, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size, riscv_vec_sort_order order)

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Number of elements to be processed

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if order is not supported

Note

  • Supported sorting orders for generic sorting (i.e., options for order) include:

    RISCV_VEC_SORT_DESCENDING

    Descending order

    RISCV_VEC_SORT_ASCENDING

    Ascending order

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements to be processed

[in] order

Sorting order
Returns

  • 0 if successful

  • -1 if order is not supported

Note

  • Supported sorting orders for generic sorting (i.e., options for order) include:

    RISCV_VEC_SORT_DESCENDING

    Descending order

    RISCV_VEC_SORT_ASCENDING

    Ascending order

Interpolation Functions

This section includes the following interpolation functions and their corresponding data structures.

Linear Interpolation Functions

Linear interpolation is a method of curve fitting using linear polynomials. Linear interpolation works by effectively drawing a straight line between two neighboring samples and returning the appropriate point along that line.

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: F32, F16, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_linear_interp_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_linear_interp_f32 (riscv_vec_linear_interp_f32_t * instance, float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Linear interpolation function for F32.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_linear_interp_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 linear interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t tbl_size;
    float32_t first_x;
    float32_t x_spacing;
    const float32_t * tbl_data;
} riscv_vec_linear_interp_f32_t;

where:

tbl_size

Number of table size

first_x

First x of the table

x_spacing

X-axis spacing

tbl_data

Pointer to the table data

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

riscv_vec_linear_interp_f16

Declaration
void riscv_vec_linear_interp_f16 (riscv_vec_linear_interp_f16_t * instance, float16_t * src, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Linear interpolation function for F16.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_linear_interp_f16_t

Instance structure of the F16 linear interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t tbl_size;
    float16_t first_x;
    float16_t x_spacing;
    const float16_t * tbl_data;
} riscv_vec_linear_interp_f16_t;

where:

tbl_size

Number of table size

first_x

First x of the table

x_spacing

X-axis spacing

tbl_data

Pointer to the table data

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

Data Structure and Parameters

[in] src

Pointer to the input vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

Bilinear Interpolation Functions

Bilinear interpolation is an extension of linear interpolation applied to a two-dimensional grid. The underlying function f(x, y) is sampled on a regular grid and the interpolation process determines the values between the grid points.

Bilinear interpolation is equivalent to two-step linear interpolation, first in the X-dimension and then in the Y-dimension.

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: F32, F16, Q31, Q15, and Q7. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f32 (riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f32_t * instance, float32_t * srcx, float32_t * srcy, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Bilinear interpolation function for F32.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 bilinear interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t row;
    uint32_t col;
    const float32_t * tbl_data;
} riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f32_t;

where:

row

Number of rows in table data

col

Number of columns in table data

tbl_data

Pointer to the table data

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src_x

Pointer to the input X coordinate vector

[in] src_y

Pointer to the input Y coordinate vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f16

Declaration
void riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f16 (riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f16_t * instance, float16_t * srcx, float16_t * srcy, float16_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Bilinear interpolation function for F16.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f16_t

Instance structure of the F16 bilinear interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t row;
    uint32_t col;
    const float16_t * tbl_data;
} riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_f16_t;

where:

row

Number of rows in table data

col

Number of columns in table data

tbl_data

Pointer to the table data

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src_x

Pointer to the input X coordinate vector

[in] src_y

Pointer to the input Y coordinate vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector
Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q31

Declaration
void riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q31 (riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q31_t * instance, q31_t * srcx, q31_t * srcy, q31_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Bilinear interpolation function for Q31.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q31_t

Instance structure of the Q31 bilinear interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t row;
    uint32_t col;
    const q31_t * tbl_data;
} riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q31_t;

where:

row

Number of rows in table data

col

Number of columns in table data

tbl_data

Pointer to the table data

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src_x

Pointer to the input X coordinate vector

[in] src_y

Pointer to the input Y coordinate vector

[out] dst

ointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q15

Declaration
void riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q15 (riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q15_t * instance, q31_t * srcx, q31_t * srcy, q15_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Bilinear interpolation function for Q15.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q15_t

Instance structure of the Q15 bilinear interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t row;
    uint32_t col;
    const q15_t * tbl_data;
} riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q15_t;

where:

row

Number of rows in table data

col

Number of columns in table data

tbl_data

Pointer to the table data

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src_x

Pointer to the input X coordinate vector

[in] src_y

Pointer to the input Y coordinate vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q7

Declaration
void riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q7 (riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q7_t * instance, q31_t * srcx, q31_t * srcy, q7_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Bilinear interpolation function for Q7.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q7_t

Instance structure of the Q7 bilinear interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    uint32_t row;
    uint32_t col;
    const q7_t * tbl_data;
} riscv_vec_bilinear_interp_q7_t;

where:

row

Number of rows in table data

col

Number of columns in table data

tbl_data

Pointer to the table data

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src_x

Pointer to the input X coordinate vector

[in] src_y

Pointer to the input Y coordinate vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

Cubic Spline Interpolation Functions

Spline interpolation is a method of interpolation where the interpolant is a piecewise-defined polynomial called spline.

You can use the riscv_vec_spline_interp_init_f32 function to calculate the coefficient of spline and call the riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32 function to get the interpolation result of the input vector.

VEC Library only supports functions for the F32 data type. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_spline_interp_init_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_spline_interp_init_f32 (riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32_t * instance, riscv_vec_spline_bound_cond cond, const float32_t * src_x, const float32_t * src_y, uint32_t nsize, float32_t * coeffs, float32_t * tmpbuf)
Description

The initialize F32 function for cubic spline interpolation.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 spline interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    riscv_vec_spline_bound_cond cond;
    const float32_t * x;
    const float32_t * y;
    uint32_t num_x;
    float32_t * coeffs;
} riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32_t;

where:

cond

Type of boundary condition

x

Pointer to the x coordinate known data

y

Pointer to the y coordinate known data

num_x

Number of known data

coeffs

Pointer to coefficient vector

[in, out] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] cond

Type of boundary condition

[in] src_x

Pointer to the x coordinate known data vector

[in] src_y

Pointer to the y coordinate known data vector

[in] nsize

Number of known data points in a vector

[in] coeffs

Pointer to the coefficient vector

[in] tmpbuf

Pointer to the temporary buffer
Note

Supported condition types for riscv_vec_spline_bound_cond include:

RISCV_VEC_SPLINE_NATURAL

Natural spline condition

RISCV_VEC_SPLINE_PARABOLIC_RUNOUT

Parabolic runout spline condition

riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32 (riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32_t * instance, const float32_t * src, float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Cubic spline interpolation function for F32.

Data Structure and Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32_t

Instance structure of the F32 spline interpolation, defined as follows:

typedef struct {
    riscv_vec_spline_bound_cond cond;
    const float32_t * x;
    const float32_t * y;
    uint32_t num_x;
    float32_t * coeffs;
} riscv_vec_spline_interp_f32_t;

where:

cond

Type of boundary condition

x

Pointer to the x coordinate known data

y

Pointer to the y coordinate known data

num_x

Number of known data

coeffs

Pointer to coefficient vector

[in] instance

Pointer to the instance structure

[in] src

Pointer to the input x value vector

[out] dst

Pointer to the output vector

[in] size

Number of elements in a vector

Window Functions

Window functions are classified into regular window functions and flat-top window functions.

Regular window functions are used to detect tones or estimate the noise. They can be categorized into the following window types according to their peak sidelobe levels (PSL):

  • Bartlett window (26.5 dB)

  • Blackman Harris window (92 dB)

  • Hamming window (42.7 dB)

  • Hanning window (31.5 dB)

  • Nuttall3 window (46.7 dB)

  • Nuttall3a window (64.2 dB)

  • Nuttall3b window (71.5 dB)

  • Nuttall4 window (60.9 dB)

  • Nuttall4a window (82.6 dB)

  • Nuttall4b window (93.3 dB)

  • Nuttall4c window (98.1 dB)

  • Welch window (21.3 dB)

Flat-top window functions are used to estimate the amplitude of a tone. They can be categorized into the following window types according to their PSL:

  • Hft90d window (90.2 dB)

  • Hft95 window (95.0 dB)

  • Hft116d window (116.8 dB)

  • Hft144d window (144.1 dB)

  • Hft169d window (169.5 dB)

  • Hft196d window (196.2 dB)

  • Hft223d window (223.0 dB)

  • Hft248d window (248.4 dB)

These window types are referenced from Spectrum and spectral density estimation by the Discrete Fourier transform (DFT), including a comprehensive list of window functions and some new flat-top windows by G. Heinzel, A. Rudiger and R. Schilling, Max-Planck-Institut für Gravitationsphysik (Albert-Einstein-Institut), Teilinstitut Hannover.

Bartlett Window Functions

These functions generate the Bartlett window with the following parameters:

Parameter Value

Peak sidelobe level

26.5 dB

Normalized equivalent noise bandwidth

1.3333 bins

3 dB bandwidth

1.2736 bins

Flatness

-1.8242 dB

Recommended overlap

50.0 %

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: F32 and F64. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_win_bartlett_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_win_bartlett_f32 (float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Bartlett window function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[out] dst

Pointer to the output generated window

[in] size

Number of samples in the window
Returns

None

[in] size

Number of samples in the window
Returns

None

Parameter Value

Peak sidelobe level

These functions generate the Hamming window with the following parameters:

Parameter Value

Peak sidelobe level

42.7 dB

1.3628 bins

1.3008 bins

Flatness

-1.7514 dB

Recommended overlap

50 %

Parameter Description

[out] dst

Pointer to the output generated window

[in] size

Number of samples in the window
Returns

None

Note

This function is supported only by toolchains that support hard-float. Additionally, you must apply the -mzfh option in both compiler and linker flags when using this function. For details about the -mzfh linking option, see Linking Options for Newlib and MCUlib Toolchains or Linking Options for Glibc Toolchains.

169.5 dB

Normalized equivalent noise bandwidth

4.8347 bins

3 dB bandwidth

4.7588 bins

Flatness

0.0017 dB

Recommended overlap

81.2 %

VEC Library supports distinct functions for the following data types: F32 and F64. These functions are described in the subsections below.

riscv_vec_win_hft169d_f32

Declaration
void riscv_vec_win_hft169d_f32 (float32_t * dst, uint32_t size)
Description

Hft169d window function for F32.

Parameters

Parameters are described as follows:

Parameter Description

[out] dst

Pointer to the output generated window

[in] size

Number of samples in the window
Returns

None

Hft196d Window Functions

These functions generate the Hft196d window with the following parameters:

Parameter Value

Peak sidelobe level

196.2 dB

Normalized equivalent noise bandwidth

5.1134 bins

3 dB bandwidth

5.0308 bins

Flatness

0.0013 dB

Recommended overlap

82.3 %
